title: 113_s2005
content: The Act may be cited as the "CLEAR Cost Information Act of 2013". It involves the reporting of certain hospital payment data. The Social Security Act is amended to include changes in subsection (a)(1), specifically in subparagraphs (V) and (W) as added by different sections of Public Law 111-148. The Social Security Act is amended by making changes to subparagraphs (V) and (W) as added by Public Law 111-148, including redesignating subparagraph (W) as subparagraph (X) and adding a new subparagraph after subparagraph (X). The Social Security Act is amended to include reporting requirements for subsection (d) hospitals to submit payment data to the Secretary in accordance with subsection (l). The Social Security Act is amended to include reporting requirements for subsection (d) hospitals to submit payment data to the Secretary for the 50 most common diagnosis-related groups and ambulatory payment classification groups. The procedures for reporting data on the 50 most common diagnosis-related groups and ambulatory payment classification groups for payment under this title must be transparent to the public. The reporting of data under this subsection must be transparent to the public and posted on a publicly accessible website for meaningful comparisons by zip code. The amendments require hospitals to report data transparently for public comparison by zip code on their website. This applies to contracts entered into or renewed after the enactment of the Act. The Act mandates that MedPAC's annual reports to Congress include information on the percentage of charity care provided by hospitals. Additionally, a report on charity care trends from certain hospitals must be made publicly available. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act now requires the Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, to post data on charity care trends from certain hospitals on a publicly accessible website allowing for comparisons by zip code. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act mandates hospitals to provide a link on their website to data that allows for comparisons by zip code and is easily understandable by consumers. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act requires hospitals to include a link on their website to data for consumer comparisons by zip code. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act mandates hospitals to include a link on their website to data for consumer comparisons by zip code, effective for contracts entered into or renewed after the enactment of the Act.
